Fig 21 Plan view showing how to determine average grade

When measuring daylight plane, height is measured from the average of the grade at the
midpoint of the building and the grade of the closest point on the abutting site.

For this side of this structure, the
average grade is the average

material

Certification of daylight plane compliance:

Upon request by the building official any person
building or making improvements to a structure shall
provide a certification that the structure, as built, com-
plies with the daylight plane provisions in Code Section
18.12.040(a). Such certification shall be prepared
by a licensed engineer, architect, or surveyor, and
shall be provided prior to frame inspection. (Sections
18.12.040(j)).

27

visual_elements.description: Figure 21: Plan view showing how to determine average grade. It depicts two adjacent properties, one with a 'Subject House' and the other with a 'Neighbor' house. Both properties have 'Front yard', 'Rear yard', and 'Interior-side yard' areas. The 'Subject House' property also shows a 'Buildable area'. Dashed lines indicate 'Required setbacks' and 'Lot line'. Arrows and text indicate how the average grade is calculated for each side of the structure, specifically as the average of grades at two points along the interior-side yard. The diagram illustrates the concept of 'Buildable area' within the lot boundaries and setbacks.
visual_elements.location: Left and middle of the page

visual_elements.description: Figure 22: Detail showing allowable eave protrusion. This is a cross-sectional view of a building's roof and wall. A 'wall plane' is shown vertically, and a 'daylight plane' is represented by a dashed line sloping downwards from the wall plane. An arrow points from the daylight plane to the intersection of the wall plane and the top of the roof material, indicating that the daylight plane must clear this point. A horizontal dimension line indicates a '2' max' protrusion from the wall plane.

A legend defining symbols used in Figure 21. 'Lot line' is a solid line, 'Required setbacks' are dashed lines, 'Sidewalk' is a patterned rectangle, 'Buildable area' is a dashed outline, and 'Existing house' is a solid grey rectangle.

logical_relationships.expression: When measuring daylight plane, height is measured from the average of the grade at the midpoint of the building AND the grade of the closest point on the abutting site.

Upon request by the building official any person building or making improvements to a structure shall provide a certification that the structure, as built, complies with the daylight plane provisions in Code Section 18.12.040(a) AND Such certification shall be prepared by a licensed engineer, architect, or surveyor AND shall be provided prior to frame inspection.

execution_sequence.action: Determine how height is measured for daylight plane.
Calculate average grade for a side of the structure.
Ensure daylight plane clears the specified point.
Provide certification for daylight plane compliance.
